The teachers and speakers were professionals and I also liked that we each got a mentor for our final project.

I attended the Ironhack Madrid Bootcamp on Jan 2014. I am a frontend dev, web designer and businessman and wanted to learn to code my own applications, not only design them. Ironhack was definitely the best choice. After the 8 weeks, I could code my own product from scratch, becoming my own developer, emphasizing on best practices and clean code, testing, etc. I recommend this awesome experience to anyone that wants to learn to code , make great networking, and build great, tested products.

a/A is a great bootcamp for anyone looking to break into field. Their curriculum is constantly changing to stay up-to-date with the market. The entire instruction team is fantastic, and the career coaches are incredibly supportive. I spent 1 month after graduation working on my portfolio, and about 2 months applying to jobs. I applied to ~250 jobs, interviewed with 5 different companies, and had two offers within 3 months of graduating. They give you all the resources to succeed, but it's up to you to put in the time and effort. Be prepared to give up your free time and weekends to learning how to code and treat the job search like a full-time job.

App Academy was my top choice for enrolling in a coding bootcamp because of it's low acceptance rate and rigorous curriculum program. Anyone can code but this program really pushes you through and through. The 24 week program is very fast paced and you will spend much time outside of normal hours studying but the depth of knowledge that you gain is worth it. Compared to many other bootcamps that I know of, App Academy prepares you well enough to provide you with strong foundational skills that other bootcamps don't give to you. This program does a great job emulating real on the job coding practices like pair programming, group projects, daily standups, and more that you can speak to in job interviews. The program is tough and the instructors and TA's are also tough on you but it really does make you a strong programmer. This program is not for those who want to coast through and hope to land a six-figure job right away, you definitely have to put in the work but by the end it'll all be worth it.

tagline: A great choice for anyone looking to break into the field
rawBody: a/A is a great option for anyone looking to break into the field. The curriculum is modern and up-to-date and constantly evolving. I enjoyed my time there and am already placed in a new role as a software engineer. As with anything that offers a high reward, you'll get out of it what you put in. I appreciate that App Academy is more rewarding for those who are self-motivated and do the work.

I loved my time at App Academy. I really value getting hands on experience and that's exactly what I got for 6 months straight. Besides just coding you learn how to work with others, how to ask questions, and how to learn things really fast. You will get to build your own projects and you will learn how to learn new technologies. By the end of the curriculum, you will have enough skills to build whatever you like. It was certainly challenging (at some points really challenging!) but if you know this is what you want to do then it quickly becomes a lot of fun as well. Pros: Really great instructors and staff that care about you and your understanding of the curriculum. Cons: Less support in the job search phase and the job search phase might be harder than the curriculum.

Be prepared to spend up many hours because App Academy is a very rigorous course because if you don't, you will struggle a lot. You expected to read/learn material ahead of the next day, so that you are able to do the projects. They also have assessments that test your skills, be ready for those tests. Once all of the assessments all done, you get to make your own websites using what you have learn over the course. The course does a good job teaching you how to apply these skills on your own project, so the course does pay off once you reach to this part of the course. Although App Academy is a pretty great course, I feel like some parts of course should be expanded upon as I felt like they were just barely a footnote. And once you finish your sites, they will provide you a lot of support to get your next job. If you don't get a job within a year, they will refund your money back. Overall, as you long as you are willing to commit your time to start a career on software engineering, I would recommend you join App Academy.

As someone who has worked various jobs in the service industry, retail, dog daycares and vet clinics, who has just began his new career as a software engineer, I can say that App Academy is responsible for guiding me through a rapid upshift in my life experience. The curriculum is very fast-paced, but not impossible! The instructors and my classmates were all so positive and we all helped each other to get through it, and to learn and grow. The projects we worked on provided a chance to immediately put into use the new knowledge and skills we picked up each week, in a cumulative manor, which was something I was unable to find on my own trying to teach myself online. The job hunt portion was the most difficult time for me mentally and emotionally, but the support I received from the staff during this point had an immeasurable impact. I'm incredibly grateful for this program. Pros: The skill of picking up new information and putting it into use, quickly, is a very valuable skill to have. This program will absolutely help you hone that skill. Also, everyone there is so positive! Cons: During group projects, not always getting to contribute an equal amount / other group members flying ahead left me feeling a little lost and unsure when it came time for solo projects. Best advice? Speak up to your group-mates! Everyone is there to help. Also, the job search portion was probably the most difficult thing I've had to do in my life. Pace yourself, and don't give up hope, IT WILL HAPPEN.

App Academy is an exceptional coding boot camp that provides a comprehensive and intensive education for those looking to launch a career in Software Engineering. From the very start, I was impressed by the quality of instruction and the dedication of the instructors to each student's success. The curriculum is well-structured and challenging, but the instructors are incredibly supportive and make sure that each student has the tools they need to succeed. The immersive program is intense, but the level of support and guidance provided by the instructors makes it a manageable and enjoyable experience. One of the things that sets App Academy apart from other coding boot camps is its focus on hands-on learning. The majority of the program is spent coding, which is an excellent way to develop real-world skills that can be applied immediately in a professional setting. The curriculum covers a wide range of topics, from front-end to back-end development, and includes everything you need to know to launch a successful career in tech. The job placement rate at App Academy is outstanding, and this is a testament to the quality of the program and the dedication of the instructors. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for the job market and are in high demand by tech companies. The network of alumni and the support provided by the career services team make it easy to find a job after graduation. In conclusion, I highly recommend App Academy to anyone looking to start a career in tech. The quality of instruction, focus on hands-on learning, and dedication of the instructors to student success make it one of the best coding boot camps available. If you're ready to take your career in tech to the next level, App Academy is the perfect place to start.

tagline: They got me a software development job.
rawBody: I did the online bootcamp during the pandemic, while abroad. App Academy is legit. It is rigorous, and you must know your stuff to move on to the next week, every week. Everyone who makes it through is well prepared for a modern software engineering role with the latest frameworks etc. The curriculum is up-to-date, so that is an advantage for bootcamp grads. But I was most impressed with the support after graduation. They keep students on track and guide you in the job search process with workshops, projects, strategies, and partnerships. Post-grad is just as rigorous as the bootcamp itself. They are motivated to support you post-graduation, unlike any other academic institution I've been involved with.

tagline: Best investment I've made in my career
rawBody: App Academy was the best investment in myself and my career I've made to date, outshining my four years spent at a top ranked college. The 24-week online program allowed more time to solidify fundamentals I now use on a regular basis, and had a pace that helped the material sink in. Pair programming and collaborating with peers on projects was particular helpful in putting lecture learnings into practice. The career planning prep support was instrumental in helping me secure my first job offer placement ~5 weeks after graduating. I've already recommended a/A to friends and have seen them complete the program as well with similar placement timelines. Definitely one of the strongest bootcamps available. Worth it!

App Academy gives as much as you put into it. And if you complete the 6 month boot camp and fully commit yourself to learning, you will come out with the skills to be an engineer. It’s not always easy, and it takes a lot of effort both for the material and the job search. But it worked for me and everyone in my cohort. Would recommend to anyone who is serious about making a career switch, or supplementing their skills!

App Academy is still one of the most rewarding educational experiences that I've ever been through up until now. Not only did I have the opportunity to work alongside many like-minded people, I was also able to develop skills which have real world impacts. For anyone looking for a career change, you won't be disappointed!

I finished App Academy's online program close to 2 years ago. During the last two years I've been able to reflect on my time there and how well it prepared me for programming work. The curriculum does a good job teaching fundamentals, but the biggest take away is it teaches you how to read docs and iterate on new concepts. During work, you'll constantly be learning new technologies, frameworks, and languages - much like my time at App Academy. I also found my first role through one of App academies career hiring presentations.

Before enrolling in the program, I had little to no experience in coding or web development. However, thanks to the dedicated and knowledgeable instructors, engaging curriculum, and hands-on projects, I was able to learn a wide range of skills and technologies in a short amount of time. App Academy not only taught me the technical aspects of web development, but also provided valuable career guidance and support. I am now confidently pursuing a career in the field and am grateful for the transformative experience provided by App Academy!

tagline: Lots of potential to learn, what you put in is what you get out
rawBody: Coming from a tech but non-software engineering background, I personally found the course to be rather intensive. I cannot speak for others who have a non-tech background. But challenges are not without rewards, I learned a lot of different technologies in a very short span of time. Just graduating from a bootcamp won't guarantee an engineering job, BUT App Academy did improve my chances of getting hired during my interview phase. Although not every company is open to bootcamp graduates, thankfully my current company was. Learning Javascript and React was the main reason for helping me land an engineering job. I'm glad to see that the current curriculum teaches Python as Ruby on Rails is not as widely used (although I've seen many positions ask for Ruby on Rails so don't sleep on this language!) In summary, App Academy provided me with the foundation and habits to unlock my engineering potential. Each student will graduate with their own variation of preferences, experience, and skills. Some will grow into dedicated backend or frontend engineers, others might work as fullstack engineers or even transition to other specialized engineering fields. My favorite part of bootcamp was learning alongside a supportive cohort & network who I still communicate and share ideas with even years after graduation!

Rigorous, yet rewarding, software engineering boot camp program. I took the 16 week course with instruction and it was packed with vital knowledge to help me get started as a software engineer. Don't think that because they have online/remote courses that the course itself will be easy. The course load is heavy, you've been warned! The program also offers a structured job search portion which continues after graduating. And I truly believe the job search support was a large part of my success in finding a job so quickly after graduating and almost worth all the tuition alone. The tuition payment plans are also very flexible.

tagline: Wish I would have done it sooner!
rawBody: The most important thing I’ll say after participating in App Academy’s 6-month online intensive boot camp is that I should have done it sooner! I’m not going to lie…it was a lot of really, really hard work. Probably the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But, what’s great about a/A besides the up-to-date curriculum and technical resources at your disposal is the support system that is in place to help you succeed. It’s a win win, and their career coaches are truly top notch. I got a job 6 weeks after graduation, and I’ve already recommended this program…and will continue to recommend it to numerous friends who have shared interest in coding!

I did App Academy during the pandemic, so I'm not sure how the in-person experience is, but the time I spent learning with App Academy was both impactful and useful. The instructors were very helpful and answered a lot of questions. You are given a lot of resources and a lot of practical work that you can add as projects on your resume. Unlike some bootcamps, you are given mentorship after graduation to help you find a career. Definitely a recommend if you choose not to do the traditional 4 years CS degree.

tagline: Honest 24-Week Online Full-Time Software Engineer Program Review
rawBody: A little about me, my previous career I was a Registered Nurse, but wish I had always gone into software and eventually landed on coding bootcamps as my attempt to become a software developer. I found it incredibly difficult to decide on which bootcamp to attend given the rising number of bootcamps out there and the high risk of many being non-legitimate. Eventually I found a few that seemed to be solid bootcamps and ultimately chose to go with App Academy based out of San Francisco/New York. If you are in the same position as I was, then you probably have researched many reviews as well and come to find that it really goes 50-50 on whether to do a coding bootcamp or not to do one. So many people say its worthless and a waste of money and how you can learn it all on your own or to pursue a computer science degree instead. Me personally? learning on my own was not going to work. Having the structure and discipline a bootcamp provides was exceedingly beneficial, especially in how they slowly advance you in learning topics. When learning on your own you get very lost in where to start and what frameworks to pick up, you end up in a constant limbo of learning small things here and there but never really gaining true knowledge of how things work. I recently completed the 6-month online software engineer track with App Academy in April of 2022. Before I started this program I spent about a month with on and off learning through websites such as Free Code Camp, Codecademy, and youtube videos. Essentially, I came in with next to know knowledge of coding. Most bootcamps are designed for people with very little coding knowledge, and build them up to speed as fast as possible. As most reviews say, attending a coding bootcamp can be very difficult and will take up most of your time. I can attest to this, It will definitely take up almost all of your time for the time you are enrolled, but I promise you it is not as hard as they say it is, it is very doable. For the 6-month online program, it was mon-fri 8am-5pm and had tests on every monday in which you need to pass to advance to the next week. You can only fail the tests or the projects (there were 4 projects total) combined of 3 times. But don't let that scare you, so many people have done this and have been successful, and App Academy does a really good job of preparing you with practice tests and office hours. They have various payment methods, which usually comes out to be around 20-22k depending on how you choose to pay. They are on the higher end of the spectrum of bootcamp affordability, but in my personal opinion, well worth it. With that said I had a great experience with App Academy and highly recommend them if you are searching for a well established bootcamp. One of the best features is that they have a career team that continues to do work shops and hiring events after you complete the program help you in your job search. I am not sure if other bootcamps do this, but this is a must, they help to keep you focused after you finish to keep learning and applying so that you will obtain that job. Don't be afraid if you do decide to choose App Academy and see that there are 100 people in your online cohort, within the first 3 weeks that number can drop in half with people deciding they don't like coding and people failing because they are not truly dedicated to learning. It is also true that most of the teachers/aides are previous students, do not be alarmed by this either, every single bootcamp does this. But do know that they have real experienced software engineers above them that also provide lectures and guide the curriculum to ensure that the correct things are being taught and that we are progressively learning. At the end of completing any bootcamp, don't expect to land a job within a few months, while it certainly does happen, it is definitely not the norm. You have to continuously work on projects/learn new concepts/study DSA/obtain certificates/ and most importantly do not stop applying to jobs. Completing the bootcamp is one part, the job search is a whole different monster, but I promise this bootcamp offers enormous help once you finish to land that job. Sorry if some of my thoughts are random through this, I am trying to put down every thing I found to be important and what I wish I had knew before I started lol. All in all if you decide on App Academy it is absolutely legit, you will learn enormous amounts, and it will be incredibly fun if you love coding. As stated above I finished in April of 2022, I just now landed a remote software engineer job this month of November 2022, it took me 6 months to land my first job and around 1000-1200 job applications. Sounds like a lot right? Many people including Computer Science graduates have this same issue in the job search. It takes a while to land that first job because everyone wants experienced engineers. Its a crappy situation, but once your in, your in. Right now the average to land that job is 6 months, sometimes sooner, and sometimes later. But it is very cool to say that I made it, from Registered Nurse to Software Engineer. I'm sure you want to hear the salary as well, it was always annoying to see people who got jobs but never listed their salary, it would be incredibly helpful if they did. For me, I am starting out at around 70k. If your in a big tech city such as San Francisco you will easily be over 100k but remember cost of living there is insane. For an entry level position I am pretty happy with that salary, within a couple years it could easily jump to 150+, but ultimately I just want to learn and grow more with a great work-life balance, so money is secondary to me. Final words, in case you were wondering if these reviews are fake or App Academy paid me to do this, they did not. That was another fear I had when searching, was that so many bootcamps had such great reviews lol. But this is absolutely my honest review, bootcamps are not for everyone, but if you truly do want to make the switch, be prepared with enough money to last you for a year, 6 months to do the program and 6 months to find a job. I hope this aides you in your search, and absolutely keep App Academy as one of your top choices if it is not already.

tagline: Fast paced but rewarding if you can ride the wave to the end! Hard work but at the end of the course, I started a new career in a very rewarding industry!
rawBody: Fast-paced but rewarding if you can ride the wave to the end! The entire course is structured in a way to gear you for success when the time comes to land your first interview. Hard work but at the end of the course, I started a new career in a very rewarding industry!

Pros: Got a job within 2-3 months of graduation Learned quickly Fullstack Engineer master of none but very flexible Cons: 70 hour work weeks Alot of self studying after class Little to no time for self interest when you are in the bootcamp you will grind!

During the pandemic, I was looking for different boot camps to get into IT as an app developer. I stumbled upon an App Academy boot camp, got tested, and signed up for a 16-week course. Great instructors who explained the material in simple and accessible language. The best job coaches were very supportive, gave us 1:1 sessions to analyze and improve soft skills, and shared their experiences and tips on interviewing. A lot of different workshops that help you stay on track Networking is the biggest plus. Support for job search coaches. Milestones projects The only comment or even advice for improvement is to update the curriculum. For example, we studied React Hooks very superficially, for the most part, we used class components

tagline: App Academy got me a job!
rawBody: App Academy ramps you up quickly to cover the core skills needed on the job. You'll be in an environment that encourages and supports your growth as an engineer so motivation is easy to come by. Your cohort will have a mix of people from all different backgrounds so your starting point in terms of coding is not important at all. The most important part of the course is the job search itself. What's great about App Academy is that there are coaches there to hold you accountable and help keep you on track. There will be lots of workshops to help you improve your white boarding skills, interviewing skills, and more. Overall, I'm really glad that I went to App Academy. Be warned the job search can be very tough and even if you have the coding chops/interviewing skills you still might have a hard time. A little bit of luck and playing the numbers game goes a long way.

App Academy helped changed my life. Lost my job in Education due to the pandemic and I wanted a new career. App Academy was an intense 16 week course which helped prepare me for my first role. As a jr developer you have a lot to learn and sometimes in short period. The intense and quick learning format of AA helped me with that as my job required me to learn C#, something AA doesn’t teach. My first role was an internship that paid a salary of $80k, double what I made in education. After 6 months I was hired on as full time from an intern and my salary was $125k and I was fully remote. So AA was intense but definitely life changing for me.

I can not say enough about how grateful I am to app academy for giving me the tools, knowledge, and networking power I needed to switch from working in special education to software engineering. From the day to day course and lectures provided by experts in the field who answered question after question (yes the same question lol) with patience, to fostering great coding skills and collaborative coding by proving daily pair boarding opportunities with other classmates, all the way to supporting me with a great career coach who didn’t rest until I was places, a/A is number one at getting you placed in your new career. Cannot stress enough the importance of pairboarding during the course, and then having access to such a vast network of software engineers when you graduate the course. Lastly, a/A’s culture is conducive to learning, growth, feeling safe, and having fun. No question is stupid, and all who are on the quest for knowledge and have respect for others are accepted, and the staff and course text try and stay hip and current!

I joined App Academy's remote program without knowing much about web development. The main stacks I learned were Ruby on Rails/React/PostgreSQL and MERN. Our daily sessions were almost all similar, with lectures in the morning and pair programming on labs in the evening. Instructors were there to help us with questions and issues. Expect A LOT of information each day. I finished the program with 3 projects for my portfolio. For the job hunt, I received help with my resume, technical interviewing, and behavioral interviewing. It was pretty much up to me to be proactive and use the resources available, which were endless (pair programming sessions, mock interviews, tech practice, and others). The job hunt assistance was available to me until I found a job. I got 2 job offers after 6 months of graduation.

If you want to change your life and learn to code, look no further. I went from not knowing how to write any code to being a Software Engineer in less than eight months, and I could not do it without the help of all the fantastic individuals at App Academy. So do yourself and your family a favor, apply, and change your life.

Enrolled in 2021 May Cohort and had a four months of a phenomenal software engineering experience with building knowledge, hands-on experience and network. Along with that, I've finished the bootcamp with three software projects which boosted my job search. Thank you aA!

I only have good things to say about AppAcademy. I graduated with a BS in Wildlife Conservation in college, but I needed something better than what jobs were available to me (better pay, better growth, and remote opportunities). I had no family or friends with any experiences with bootcamps, so I did my own research and went for it. I chose AppAcademy because it has a true 'pay after you land your first job' model (didn't pay a penny until I landed my first job. No security deposit) AND because it ranked high on all bootcamp charts, AND because I knew it would be very difficult (better quality education). I wasn't disappointed. Within a month of graduation I was hired as a Senior Software Engineer at an international company that has over 5,000 employees. Definitely one of the best investments of my life. I have recommended this bootcamp to so my people - friends, family, and strangers. I love what I do. My pay, social status, and quality of life and all significantly improved.

App Academy was more than just an academic institution to me. It taught me many life lesson that I will carry with me throughout my entire life. I was part of the 24-week online curriculum, and not only did I learn the full stack of software development, I sharpened a lot of soft skills that will benefit me in and out of the office, such as communication, collaboration, and most importantly the ability to teach myself complicated material. To be completely honest, App Academy is vigorous, and not for everyone. But if you're serious about changing your career path, be ready to put in the work and constantly be pushed out of your comfort zone. I wish you all good luck on your endeavors.

Overall a really good experience and helped me land an amazing job. I would suggest getting some coding experience before applying or attending or it will be much more difficult. If you don't have a mac I would highly suggest getting or borrowing one as it will make your life easier with their specific program.

Anyone who's thinking about becoming a software engineer should definitely join App Academy, especially if you're tight on money! They've been true to their word in every aspect. I didn't have to pay a cent until I found a job. Yes, the hours are long and the material can be difficult, but definitely worth it in the end

App Academy is a very intense coding bootcamp but it is definently worth it. I learned a lot in a short amount of time and was able to land a great job afterwards. Although it can seem daunting I would definently recommend it to anyone who is looking to break into the tech industry

Overall I had a good experience. Learned a lot about programming and developing web applications. Instructors and TAs are great, they are very supportive and passionate for what they do. Technologies covered include JS, Python, React, Express, and Flask just to name a few. Learning these builds a foundation for you to learn other technologies once you finish. However, there weren't any CSS frameworks that they covered which was a little disappointing. Also I feel more emphasis could be put into learning DS&A which I feel is a big part of the interview process. With that said this is a rigorous and stressful curriculum itself and there is a strike system implemented that just adds unnecessary stress in my opinion. But if you take the time to prepare before the bootcamp starts and actually study you will make it to the end.

tagline: A tough yet worth while experience that will level up your software engineering skills.
rawBody: I just graduated from the full-time online program in September 2022 and I feel much more confident that I can achieve my goal of working as a software engineer. The instructors were always willing to help and they accommodate very well to people who are completely new to programming. App Academy does a phenomenal job at deep diving into React and Redux and you should feel confident that you can develop a full-stack app from scratch when you complete the program. However, I feel the DS&A curriculum should be either extended or be something that we have to be doing throughout the program because after Module 2 you don't really get to practice it and it's just something we have to start practicing when we start looking for a job. Overall, I met some people that are now lifelong friends, and if you work HARD; you will succeed in the program and be job ready once you graduate.

tagline: An incredibly informative and lifechanging experience
rawBody: App Academy's free resources were one of the first resources I found that actually began to speed up my learning process when I was learning code by myself, and it hooked me so well that I knew I had to take the full time course to speed things up. I can easily say it was one of the best decisions I ever made. Every experience I had in the program was a good one. I had the pleasure of having AMAZING coaches throughout, the coursework was concise, efficient, and PACKED full of real-world, applicable knowledge that I use everyday now. I can't imagine breaking into the industry any other way having done App Academy now. I am a week out of graduation with people already reaching out to me thanks to the incredible networking setup they had us do. I'm hoping to use my momentum now to break into big tech, and I know that even if I can't do it right away, App Academy has given me the tools and skills I need to get there soon. Can't recommend them enough!

Throughout the Bootcamp, my social life fell apart for most of the week. I can tell many other students spent every second coding and sacrificed time with loved ones, but in the end, it was worth it. We all learned many marketable skills that employers will be looking for, and I would do it again.

App Academy was an outstanding and truly exceptional experience. I will admit that I did not realize how intense it was going to be but it was well worth my time. App Academy (a/A) really makes sure that its students know and fully understand the material. They highly encourage questions at all times and there are instructional assistants that can help you all along the way if you need it. If it were not hard, a/A would not be one of the best. I chose to attend the 24 week online full time bootcamp (despite living in the SF Bay Area) because that was the best choice for me. I do come from an engineering background and had an engineering degree with a bit of programming experience before attending a/A. This truly didn't matter as there were students that excelled with no degree and no pervious experience. This bootcamp will consume close to your entire life for the 6 month duration, be ready for it. If I were to estimate, I believe I was putting in close to 10 hour days every single day for 6 months which includes weekends. I truly believe that all the struggle and long nights were worth it. After completing the program I absolutely feel prepared to work as a software engineer. Lastly, I would like to mention an extremely important perk that a/A offers that most other boot camps do not. After graduating, each student is given a career coach to help perfect/improve all necessary assets for the job search (resume, projects, etc.) Your coach will help you strategist to get you the job you actually want and even help with salary and benefit negotiations when the time comes. All in all, I highly recommend a/A but you had to be ready to give up your life for 6 months and work your butt off for an unbelievable reward. If it were easy, everyone would do it.

tagline: This course will take you through the wringer, but change your life!
rawBody: Before taking this course, I worked in hospitality - while it was rewarding, I felt as if I had hit a skill cap. I had been in hospitality 10 years and it was time for a change. I always considered myself a bit of an over-achiever, and I thought learning code would be easy. I was sorely mistaken, this course was TOUGH. You will need to dedicate at least 50 hours a week. But in the end, it is all so worth it. You gain invaluable skills to improve your life!

tagline: Very fast-paced and long hours, but well worth it in the end.
rawBody: I took the online 24 week full time bootcamp. Pros were the project weeks, where you actually build out full stack applications from scratch, and the pair programming. I think these two attributes of AA are its strongest because it helps to talk about code with someone else to really understand it. Some cons were the extremely long hours, sometimes potentially 12-15 hour work days, and just how fast paced the program is. With the sheer amount of material you learn in the 6 months, it can be quite a lot. Worth it tho.

It was great experience with App Academy. Over 24 weeks, you will learn all the skills needed to begin as a software engineer. If you do not have any prior programming experience, it will be really difficult for you. You will definitely need to work really hard throughout the bootcamp. But it is totally worth as you become a really good full stack software engineer after 24 weeks.

The a/A teaching staff is wonderful. As alumni, knowing how rigorous and challenging the program is, they do their very best to help you succeed and can empathize with your journey. Stay disciplined and on top of your work and the benefits you will reap in the end will make this journey worthwhile. What is special about a/A is that they don't throw you to the wolves when the program is over... You are matched with a career coach that will provide guidance until you find a career. I've just begun my job search and already feel overwhelmed however knowing that I have a team to lean on for support especially in these times of a recession and a hiring freeze, I know I am in good hands. a/A also provides Zoom events where you can meet with companies a/A has partnered with where graduates can connect with recruiters, employees, and even founders of those companies. All in all, the skills I've developed throughout my time at a/A is something I am very proud of. I wouldn't have ever thought I'd be able to construct and design full-stack web applications, let alone be able to call myself an engineer! If you are considering joining a software engineering bootcamp, it should 100% be App Academy! Then you can pride yourself in having graduated from one of the top coding bootcamps with a less than 3% acceptance rate.

The curriculum was well-crafted. Also, there is bonus curriculum content after finishing the program. It is a lot of information condensed, but you gain the ability to apply it immediately. If there's anything I would do differently, I would try to practice spaced repetition to really hone in the concepts. Enjoy the process and try to soak in as much information as you can!

I graduated with a BS in Fashion Merchandising. When the pandemic began, it became more difficult to get a career within my field. I knew I wanted to go back to school with the intent of a career change but I didn't want to spend 2+ more years in college for a career that wasn't guaranteed. Then I found App Academy through a friend and it has been the best decision I have ever made -- academic wise. This bootcamp is designed for anyone looking to change their careers into tech without a tech background. However, I highly recommend anyone interested in this program to do some self studying for a few months prior to applying, as the application process and bootcamp itself is a rigorous and fast paced experience. App Academy has great resources for job seekers/alumni, especially a huge career partnership network. I would recommend this experience to anyone, but be sure to come prepared!

tagline: Good support system and curriculum structure
rawBody: Supportive instructors and TAs who care about your learning process. Good explanations and curriculum, even though the pace is fast and rigorous, but that's why it's a bootcamp. The structure of each day is pretty good and kept my time well-managed. Cohort mates were very friendly and generous to work with, so it made my time at App Academy more enjoyable than expected! Made fun projects as well.

tagline: Hands down one of the best boot camps.
rawBody: Though one of the more stressful and intensive times of my life, attending App Academy was definitely one of the best investments I've made. Prior to a/A, I did not have any technical coding experience other than small little resources online and through eBooks. The curriculum was pretty fast paced, but definitely manageable as long as you're putting in the work. They warned us that throughout this bootcamp, you will live and breathe code, and they were not wrong. I clocked in over 80 hours of work every week, but this amount of effort probably wasn't necessary just to simply pass the weekly assessments. Instructional staff were all very nice, understandable, and willing to help. Definitely take advantage of the TA's and ask for help! I made the mistake of wanting to try to figure things out myself, but my time would have been saved if I just called in a TA and ask for help. MAKE SURE TO EXERCISE PENCILED IN YOUR SCHEDULE; you will be sitting all day. Make friends! Coding is more fun with a small group than with yourself. Also encourage people to work with their classmates to learn about their perspectives and their way to doing things. In regards to a/A's downsides, there were a couple typos in the curriculum. Another downside would be the transition between each module. When you get near the end of a module, you start to get used to your instructor, and right when you get comfortable, you move on to a new module with a brand new instructor, and you get right into work. Overall, great experience!

I really enjoyed my time at App Academy. It was an amazing experience for six months. I loved the staff, they were all very welcoming and understanding. They also provided resources for outside of study materials. App Academy gave me access to a therapist and it really helped my mental health during the boot camp. I also appreciate the new friends I have made in the boot camp. I came in with the expectation of not making new friends or getting close with anyone but I am glad I was completely wrong. I know that I enjoyed my time during App Academy due to the staff and friends I have made. I would always look forward to attending class and working with new people every day. The only con was the long time commitment of six months but it was definitely worth every second. I would recommend this course to others any time.

tagline: No background in Coding? Don't Worry! App Academy provides that for you!
rawBody: App Academy is great in that it provides structure, a great curriculum, and a foundation that allows anybody to become a programmer. I had no prior knowledge in coding and did not know how to code at all. App academy's structure provides a great foundation for students who do not know how to code. Their emphasis is that they want you to learn and understand rather than go through the curriculum. They implement this by having weekly assessments, that'll determine whether the student understands the topic enough to move onto the next topic. I would suggest that if you're not ready to devote your time to study outside of the curriculum then you will not pass. You're given three deferrals and if you don't pass the third time then you're out of the program. Another pro about the program is that it provides a lot of help in the job search when you graduate. Overall, I would say that app academy does a great job in providing the education, care and support for those that want to learn and will put in the effort to learn as much as possible.

tagline: An amazing bootcamp and experience to transition into tech
rawBody: It was an amazing experience for me to be able to learn how to code without any prior knowledge. In addition to meeting amazing people, I learned how to code and developed my technical skills. The App Academy was intense and fast-paced because they were trying to teach so much material within 4 months, so you might not fully understand all the concepts right away, but it builds that foundation so you can review it later. The working environment at my first job as a software engineer was very similar to App Academy's structure, which emphasizes adapting and learning new technologies along with pair programming. Overall, App Academy was an amazing experience where I was able to meet new people, learn how to code, and land my first role as a software engineer.

Pros: Really dive deep into the ins and outs of coding. A lot of my classmates came from a non-engineering background and we were able to follow along. The support given after bootcamp was amazing. You have your own career coach who helps you with the job process. My coach helped me navigate negotiating salary when I got my job offer 1 and a half months after I graduated. Cons: Long Long Long study hours during class, after class, after program ends. I was waking up at 7AM to study until 9AM. 9AM-6PM is class and then 6AM - 1AM studying. Curriculum is about the same at every bootcamp. A easy to learn backend language and React/Redux/Javascript for the frontend.

tagline: Prepares you from start to finish, no experience needed.
rawBody: The program is pretty intensive, given that it's a full time commitment. This said, the staff really do a good job of walking through the day to day and the ever-improving curriculum prepares you from any beginner level to being ready to apply for jobs right out of bootcamp.

tagline: App Academy was one of the best experiences of my life
rawBody: I joined App Academy with no prior coding experience and I believe that I came out with a solid understanding of web development. The program was no small feat and you definitely need to put in the work, but for as little as just 4 months of your time, it was for sure worth it! Probably the biggest skill that I've learned early on in the program was how to use the debugger. This allowed me to debug my code as well as other people's code and figure out what every single line of code is doing. Definitely a great tool for beginners if they want strong fundamentals and a better understanding of the code that they write.

Pros: 3 different complete projects. Each one significantly different from the other. Two are fullstack apps, one using MERN and the other Ruby on Rails. The last is a frontend only javascript app. 2 languages. You learn basics of programming in ruby and then switch in the middle to javascript. You are forced to learn a new language in a short amount of time which I can attest is very helpful in the real world. Cons: Staffing issues, students are finding jobs and the teacher positions can't compete.

tagline: Good for those who don't know where to start
rawBody: App Academy has team of instructors who give lectures on SW topics and help with projects. These instructors and the job search coaches are recent graduates from AA who are also doing their own job search. The projects were fun to work on and helped me put into practice the knowledge and skills that I was gaining from the curriculum and from working with other peers. AA makes sure you adhere to deadlines and stay on top of your projects and job search. This bootcamp is useful if you need some extra encouragement and direction in software engineering. On the curriculum: You will learn Ruby, Ruby on Rails, SQL, Active Record, JavaScript, React and Redux. There is very little on CS topics and ultimately when you finish the curriculum, they tell you to go back and study data structures and algorithms on your own and via LeetCode because that is what companies will interview you on. There is an assessment almost every week for the first 2 months and will have very thorough practice tests and some will just be a simple practice test. Instructors will tell you to do each practice test at least 10x over the weekend and the assessments are mostly memorization of material. Every night there is homework to do each night to prep you for the project you will do pair programming with the next day. The quality of this material can vary greatly from topic to topic. Post curriculum: Once you finish the 16-week curriculum, you have to do 3 projects (JavaScript, Fullstack and MERN, with MERN being a group project) which will become your portfolio projects. Once these are done, their job search team will guide you through the process of making job search materials. This will includes resume, cover letter, portfolio website, creating GitHub, LinkedIn and AngelList profiles, and how to give a personal pitch. So far I have received wonderful feedback from coaches (also past graduates). For those who are good at self study, you probably won't need AA because their curriculum is the same as their free online curriculum, or other free resources online. Communication with their team can be disorganized as they don't have a consistent platform to share information (including what is expected of each student). There were a couple things that caught us off guard and was a bit frustrating: * We were initially told passing scores for assessments are 50% but once you start, they tell you its 85% * They do not use Slack Premium, so you will not be able to look at communication that is over 1 week old * Deadlines for various tasks may be given in Zoom chats, Slack or verbally (inconsistent) - It would have been best if they used email * They have a bot that emails nightly with information needed but they are not updated - often we received deadlines for previous cohorts * All marketing says it's a 16-week program but after the 16-weeks, they begin the job search period which you are still required to attend for at least the first couple weeks after graduation, meaning you can't make vacation plans, this should have been better communicated prior to signing onto bootcamp Ultimately, it depends on what you want to get out of a bootcamp. They provide a set curriculum and structure for those who need it, which I like to have. I really enjoyed meeting people from a very diverse collection of backgrounds and learning from each of them. I also had a lot of fun using the knowledge learned to do the final projects. Since instructors are past grads, there is quite a bit of turnover and I think each cohort's experience will vary greatly depending on the team of instructors. It's a very good start for anyone who doesn't have a technical background and doesn't know how to start, or what materials to study on their own.

As someone with zero background with software engineering / coding, I thoroughly enjoyed and learned a lot from their well-crafted curriculum. The course is quite rigorous, and the instructors are super attentive. Everybody is super welcoming and willing to help one another out - instructors and students alike. I look forward to the job search and applying the skills that I have acquired over the last few months.

The last couple of months have been life changing. The program is intense, but the instructional staff provides great support. I didn't have a lot of prior experience in programming before starting, but now I can build a full stack application. You will definitely learn a lot during the program and put in lots of work but it's all worth it in the end. I had an amazing time and would recommend.

The instructors explained lectures in a timely and orderly fashion. The curriculum was well-crafted by team of highly-respected professionals. Every day, I could not have been more excited to arrive to App Academy, as the lectures were paced appropriately and staff were welcoming. Learning how to be a full-stack engineer was amazing. Meeting great colleagues was enjoyable. At anytime, I could always ask staff for help, as I truly looked up to them. It was my honor to be here. I'd like to thank the team at App Academy for bringing lots of great experiences.

Pros: - AppAcademy has a great network of alumni - Course is well-designed and allows students to explore different technologies / APIs during their projects - Career coaches are experienced professionals who teach the best methods Cons: - Curriculum is outdated (Bootcamp utilizes version 5.2.3 for Ruby on Rails and uses Heroku Stack-18 which will be deprecated soon) - Some New York City Instructors lacked experience in teaching, making it difficult for some students to grasp concepts - Fast-paced; not a course for individuals who prefer a slower pace or wants to laze about

My husband went to App Acadamy about 5 years a go. When I needed to choose a bootcamp, he highly recommended it. The past 6 months at App Acadamy is truly life changing. The staff and instructors were all very knowledgeable and supportive, and most of my cohort mates were easy to get along with. The best of all was the curriculum design. Even though the pace was intense, it all makes sense learning one after the other.

App Academy has truly been a blessing to experience. From the course material, to the classmates and teachers, it was an absolute blast to be a part of since day 1. The curriculum was intense most of the time, but this was built specifically to learn the most efficiently. Loved my time with everyone and I am now very excited to begin my career as a Full Stack Software Developer!

tagline: Excellent experience, but a lot of work
rawBody: I had a great experience with App Academy. The curriculum was excellent, and I think a huge part of the value is the assistance with the job search after you complete the program, for up to a year. I would recommend a/A to anyone looking for a serious web development bootcamp. It is, however, very difficult. I attended the full-time online program lasting 6 months. The majority of the students that started in my cohort were deferred (meaning you did not pass an assessment and are rolled back to the previous cohort to retake the last month's material - you get 3 deferrals and are dismissed on the 4th). The advertised 60-80 hours of work a week is no joke. The program is certainly not for everyone - you will get out of this program what you put into it. They are constantly updating the curriculum as technologies change, which can be frustrating, but this is a real-life part of being a developer. The emphasis on pair programming also turns some folks off, but once I got used to it I came to really appreciate the approach. Bottom line: If you are not planning to dedicate yourself fully to this bootcamp for 6 months, do not attend. But if you are willing to live breathe and sleep code and comp sci for 6 months to facilitate a career start or a career change, I can't think of a better option than a/A.

When I was looking over various bootcamps, the one con that I saw with App Academy was how long it was. Going through the program I definitely understood why it was longer than the others. With how the program is set up, I feel like you actually get to learn the material with pair programming and figuring things out yourself. Going through some weeks I was very lost early in the week, but because of the structure by Thursday or Friday I felt very comfortable with the material. There were few weeks were I was stressing over the weekend because the homework and practices helped to iron out anywhere I was struggling during the week. There are TAs available along the way, but the cohort mates are your best resource as you're all in the same stage. I enjoyed the course and made some invaluable connections through the program.

I originally come from an accounting/finance background. I was a property account manager and loved problem solving. Decided to make a career switch to SWE after hearing that my brother and cousin went through a/A and landed successful jobs doing what I loved about my previous role. I took some preliminary courses on a/A open, and decided to go all in to the 24 week online program. I had no background in coding, but I was able to learn Javascript/Python, sequelize/sqlalchemy, react and redux, and much more. I was able to get great team building experiences and make 2 projects. I also got the chance to showcase my individual ability with 2 solo projects. App academy instructors are caring and very helpful. They also offer great coaching and guidance to graduates in order to help them land a job. My biggest advice for anyone looking to join is to be seriously prepare to give up your free time, and be open to studying in groups. A lot of people I know that didn’t want to put the games/partying down didn’t make it through the program. Many of the people who refuse to work with others and attend study groups at night also struggled to learn and pass. I highly recommend a/A for anyone seriously committed to making the switch to SWE and getting a solid foundation for a career in SWE.

tagline: The most formative/intense/amazing 6 months of my life!
rawBody: Going into App Academy I had minimal knowledge of software development. I had done some self-studying but never with the intensity or schedule that App Academy provides. I had wanted to do a career switch for a while back then and after reviewing several coding bootcamps I decided to go with App Academy. To me what was very attractive about the program was the schedule and the rigor of the course. I feel like deep diving like App Academy does, in a short time frame, but allowing you to fully take in the information, is the most efficient way of learning. I truly do believe I have learned more in these 6 months than in my 4 years in college. Also, the connections you make with your peers will only lead to potential future opportunities which is a win-win for all parties involved! Would definitely recommend this Bootcamp to anyone interested in efficiently learning about the fascinating world of software development.

tagline: A hard, but rewarding experience made all the better by my fantastic classmates.
rawBody: Disclosure: while I did the 16-Week program, it was online rather than in person due to Covid. For me, App Academy was a great experience. From great instructors to amazing cohort mates, the people are what made the journey fun and enjoyable. When I started, I expected to be pretty much isolated from the rest of the world for 4 months coding online. However, App Academy's friendly instructors and my fellow cohort mates made the physical isolation feel like nothing as I would log in every day looking forward to talking and learning to code with them. The course, while challenging (I put in 70-80 hours a week), was fair and the material was taught in a clear, step-wise manner that allowed for ideas to reinforce each other day after day. After my graduation was where I thought I got the most bang for my buck. My career coach gave me wonderful and insightful advice to clean up job application materials as well as how to properly prepare for interviews. That advice resulted in me being offer three software engineering jobs within 2 months of graduating with one being well over 120k a year. The cons of App Academy are two fold 1) the cost as compared to other boot camps with deferred payment tuition plans, such as Hack Reactor, and 2) during the program, sometimes the daily emails would contradict what was said in lecture. I can without hesitation recommend the App Academy program to those who are looking to enter tech from a non-tech background.

tagline: Best way to learn the skills needed and to become a software developer
rawBody: I joined the 24-week Immersive Full Stack Online Program in December 2021 and graduated in June 2022. As someone who was looking to make a career change, I recommend App Academy as it provided me with the best way to learn coding starting with my level. I had taken some computer science classes back in college, but was overwhelmed because I didn't have prior knowledge in the field in order to learn the hard concepts. App Academy's materials assumed that students wouldn't have any prior knowledge, so they were the right kind of teaching materials that I needed to finally learn and master the skills. The staff at App Academy was really supportive as most of them came from a background of graduating from a coding bootcamp. Fellow students of my cohort were amazing, helping one another learn and succeed throughout the journey. After graduation, there's a job placement team that's dedicated to help you succeed in the job search process.

tagline: App Academy is the perfect way to learn the skills needed to break into tech!
rawBody: As someone who wanted to leave the business world and start a career as a software engineer, App Academy provided the structure and resources I needed to take that step. Over the course of 16 weeks, I learned all of the skills needed to land my first job as a software engineer and more importantly built my confidence as a developer. I highly recommend this program to anyone looking to break into tech and to become a software engineer in a collaborative, challenging, and rewarding environment.

I enrolled in the Full Stack Online Immersive 24-Week Program in December 2021 and graduated in June 2022, during my time at App Academy I met tons of people that helped me to grow, particularly the staff and lecturers. I learned 2 technology stacks and reinforced my knowledge of the fundamentals. I was stressed at times and only made it through because of the help of the staff and my peers. If I could change one thing it would be to go in person since I feel I'm better at learning in person.

tagline: App Academy not only molds you into a better person but sets you up to be a great Software Engineer
rawBody: This course separates those who can and those who can’t. If you are wondering what it takes to become a Full Stack Dev, look no further than App Academy. The value of this course is absolutely worth it. But don’t be fooled that it will be easy, it requires all your effort, attention and focus.

I changed career in my mid-30s and App Academy made it possible for me through their curriculums and support. a/A is no joke! They expect students to spend ~70 hours a week and I actually spent more hours each week throughout the entire 16-week period. It’s a 2x full-time job. If you are unable to fully commit to it, don’t bother because most likely they will kick you out - there’s an assessment almost every week and if failed more than two, you are out! By the 4th week of my cohort, half of the cohort mates were gone. At the end of the 16th week, only one-third of cohort mates were able to make it to graduation. We had an instructor and 3 instructor assistants. They were knowledgeable about the learning materials and were able to explain very well whenever we had questions. In order to graduate, we had to have three projects - a javascript, full-stack, and team-collaboration full-stack project. These are keys to landing a job, especially if you had no prior experience in the software engineering field. I am glad they had this as part of their curriculum! After graduation, technical and behavior coaches did a fantastic job preparing me for the interview process. In the 3rd week of the job-hunting process, I had more interviews scheduled than I could handle so I had to slow down my application submission. I got two offers by the end of the 4th week and accepted one. Now working as a Software Engineer in a public traded company and loving it! Overall, based on my own experience, a/A is a legit Bootcamp school with organized curriculums and support teams to prepare people with no coding experience for the tech field.

tagline: If you need structure, do App Academy
rawBody: Finding self studying hard? Don't know where to start with coding? A bootcamp may be for you! App Academy has an amazing support system, whether it be the mod leads, the TAs, to your own cohort mates. It is fast-paced though, and if you don't study or do the homework, you will fall behind. It's for your own benefit, anyways! Now that I'm in job search, I can full-heartedly say that my career coach is absolutely amazing and super helpful. A tip I would give is to start practicing DS&A problems halfway through the bootcamp on your own so you don't have to stress about it as much like I am right now after the bootcamp. This bootcamp give you amazing pair programming experiences to talk about, and also group projects and solo projects for your portfolio. If I could do it again, I would, and I would start doing one DS&A problem every day or every other day or something.. starting from week 7 probably. I would definitely recommend App Academy though!

I decided to enroll in the 6-month full-time online software engineering bootcamp and it was one of the best decisions that I have made. It is an intensive course that requires a time commitment of 60-80 hours per week due to the very fast-paced nature of the course, but no prior experience is required and I feel like I have a solid foundation of knowledge to enter the tech industry for the first time. The TAs were very helpful in helping me understand some of the more difficult concepts. I have made many friends in the process of taking this course as well. I highly recommend this course if you are trying to enter the tech industry for the first time as a software engineer and don't know where to start.

tagline: App Academy is a place where they teach you how to learn efficiently and effectively
rawBody: App Academy is good at what it does, it teaches you how to learn things fast and apply them. The program is very fast paced and you do learn a lot, and when I say a lot I mean a lot. I took the 24 week online program, and it was a good experience especially during the pandemic. It was hard, but doable if you do the homework and put in effort to study for the assessments. There was only really two weeks that were really hard, but overall I passed without deferring once. The Cons of App Academy are maybe the strike system? I mean if you have 3 alarms for each check in you theoretically should not get any strikes. I am currently in the sprint week, so I do not have any opinion on the job support yet, but so far the leads for jobs are good, the workshops available seem helpful as well. Overall I would recommend App Academy to someone looking into a bootcamp. I do want to say that you should have a general knowledge of coding or take a prep course before starting(not required), but it helps you get through the first few weeks easier.

tagline: If you are unhappy with your career, take the leap!
rawBody: To anyone considering changing career paths, I couldn’t recommend App Academy enough! Before I applied, I watched countless YouTube videos and read many reviews and reddit forums about whether or not App Academy was for me. I never really heard anything bad about them so it almost seemed cult-ish but after eventually doing it, I can see why so many people recommend because it changed my life. I was working at a dead-end job as a landscaper, and couldn’t afford to move out of my parents house. I dropped out of college because it was two expensive and didn’t really have any other plan. I knew a few people who attended App Academy and decided to pull the trigger and quit both my jobs. I did the JavaScript Bootcamp prep which was kind of expensive but I did think that it gave me a head start on learning JavaScript. Although, in hindsight, there are many online resources that would’ve made a great alternative as well! I did the 16-week Ruby immerse program and it was tough. Very tough. I for-sure had a few mental breakdowns about passing exams but looking back, there is nothing they teach that it too complicated to learn, it’s just a lot in a short amount of time. You need to know how to pace yourself so you don’t burn out and I recommend getting as far ahead in App Academy Open before starting the official course. And do the homework! It is very important! After the 16 weeks, I was able to get a fully remote frontend developer role paying 90k+ one week after graduating. It seems like it’s almost too good to be true but App Academy really does prepare you for a job not only the curriculum, but also helping prepare your LinkedIn/ social platforms and mock interviewing. If you are uncomfortable with your life, take the leap!!

tagline: For what it is, it did teach me a lot.
rawBody: Even though the program is set up to be a guided course with plenty of staff to help you along the way, I did feel that many times the amount of help needed to understand concepts by my classmates and I was lacking. There were many times where the TA's or IA's were not knowledgeable in what the subject matter called for and left many students lacking. When you realize that you were not going to be able to get the type of help needed to fully understand the subject it came down to buckling down and be able to teach yourself at the end of the day.

tagline: Stepping stone to a new adventure.
rawBody: The course is very intense, and requires you to learn a lot in a short time. If you are the type of person who can lock in and persevere through any obstacle, this is definitely for you. You don't need any prior knowledge, I came in directly from working in a lab with a chemistry background. Everything you need to know, they will teach you, and plenty of help from instructors are provided. However, I definitely recommend, more prep is always best. Also, before starting this journey, please ensure you are financially ready. Though the course is 6 months, it can easily turn into a year. Timeline varies for everyone, if you defer multiple times, or how long the job search lasts for you. Don't be ashamed of deferring, people who were smarter than I deferred, which is why you should plan for it, if taking this course. From this point on, you must plan for any scenario in your life. This will make you a better coder, and person. I definitely would do this course again, and recommend it to those with a creative, and problem solving mind. I wish I would have done something like this sooner.

The curriculum will feel very vigorous and intense just like a daily dose of regretful bloat post-pie-eating contest if you aren't mentally ready to work 80+ hours a week. You can only fail 1 test and have 1 chance to retake, which used to give me nightmares. Speaking of which, while I know it's tempting, I've regretted every single day I sacrificed sleep. Nothing's worse than a brain trying to focus on multiple lines of code for ~8 hours. Describing learning and retaining the material always gives me a visual of drinking from a fire hose while struggling to hold in stomach contents. You don't need prior coding knowledge (although boot camp prep will help a lot), but you do need to know how to make friends. Or at least... you know that customer in line that likes to brag about having lots of money? That same person who mistreats customer service and wastes the time of other customers even though you're all in the same line together? And then hopefully gets their credit card declined as a gift from karma? Don't be that person! The other students will be trying to drink out of that water hose with you, and if you can help each other, at least you don't have to cry alone. So, put that ego away and get ready to welcome your fellow comrades with open arms~ The TAs are seasoned veterans of said fire hose with big hearts and determination to help you through as they were once students too. If you get through this program, it will feel surreal and humbling. No program is perfect and some materials need a major update, but it was worth it.

tagline: Great if you are looking to change careers!
rawBody: I had a good experience while attending App Academy and made strong connections with my cohort mates, allowing me to succeed in this program. Previously, I had been working toward my CS degree and decided that I wanted a more immersive learning experience where I could utilize the skills I learned to build applications. If you are looking for a Bootcamp to challenge you and allow you to grow then a/A is a great choice. Each week you will be challenged and surprise yourself with how much you can do if you put in the time and effort. Although the program can be difficult at times, it prepares you for what you will need to do on the job.

I graduated from AppAcademy 24 week program in March 2022. It was a great experience for me. I was working in the fashion industry before that and have no coding background. This program taught me how to become an independent programmer and solve problems (debugging). I was very lucky to be in an awesome class where all my classmates are very nice, smart, professional, and positive. All my classmates became my network after we graduated. It is very important to know that: Do not expect anyone will hold your hand and feed you all the knowledge, the point here is to learn HOW TO LEARN ON YOUR OWN. It is very important in this industry because you will constantly need to learn new things and no one has the time to teach you one-on-one all day. Of course you can ask questions any time during AppAcademy, but try to ask good questions. Try to research or try solving before reaching for help.

tagline: Better than going the self-taught route
rawBody: After much deliberation between going the self-taught route versus attending a bootcamp, I enrolled in the 16-week online program focused on Javascript and Ruby on Rails. Without a doubt, attending App Academy has been one of the best decisions of my life. Attending the program gives you a support network of TAs and peers who are with you each step of the way to keep you motivated and to hold you accountable, which is something I would have missed had I decided to teach myself to code. Who knows how long the projects would have taken me to complete had I decided to try to code for X or Y hours each day? The coursework is challenging and for the most part is very hands-off - you get out what you put in. I still recall one review of App Academy that I saw before attending and the punchline read something like "Sure you could teach your self to code, but who knows how long that will take. You'd probably get a job and start making money 1/4 of a year earlier with A/a which would offset the cost of the program very quickly."

My dive into software engineering was very spontaneous, and I chose App Academy almost purely on the fact that I know a few successful graduates. However, I definitely do not regret choosing this bootcamp. I attended their 16 week program and spent 80+ hours a week learning all sorts of skills such as React, Javascript, Ruby, Ruby on Rails, and more. We constructed 3 separate projects with the material we learned, and this really helped cement the skills into my head. My only gripe with the curriculum is that it felt a little outdated. I would have preferred learning Python over Ruby and maybe learned a bit more about React hooks as well. The teaching staff was exceptionally helpful and really did try their best to help you learn. My cohort started at a little over 30 people and ended with about 20, so it definitely is quite the rigorous program. The career coaches have been great so far and they really seem to know what they are doing. Job support seems very well structured and aimed at securing you a job as quickly as possible. Overall, a great bootcamp where you can not only change your life, but meet awesome people along the way!

The experience was amazing, being able to meet and experience the 16 week journey with the cohort and making some lifelong friends along the way. The curriculum felt mostly self-driven, because the guidance offered got looser and looser over time, but that helped build strong habits and good problem solving, since it was mostly up to you to learn the material. With this style of learning, the more you put into it, the more you get. Personally, I found it very rewarding, and going through with my cohort-mates and asking a lot of questions helped me feel confident to solve any problem I'll be faced with in the future.

I decided last year to sign up for app academy. I was a beginner coder with only enough experience to pass the requirements to get accepted. I had a great time meeting new friends and very smart people along the way. The instructors are very good and skilled to explain everything you need in the class. The technical instructors are also amazing across all the modules, they are always there to help and don't hesitate to answer any questions. The structure of the program is also very good. Now that I have been through it, I feel like it is well structured to optimize the amount of material students learn each week. The job search support and the career coaching that is available is also great. Not many coding bootcamps have this kind of support to really set all students for success. I had a great experience and would definitely do it again! The one thing I would do differently now is, that I would take some time prior to starting the bootcamp to study up to set myself for a success from Day 1. Unfortunately, since I did not have any experience prior to starting aA, I felt very overwhelmed especially at the beginning which resolved in the deferral in the first few weeks. After that I was able to catch up, understand the basics and create a momentum to be successful in the program. Again, if you are thinking about joining a bootcamp or not sure about which one, I cannot recommend App Academy enough. It is money well spend and I would do it all over again.

Attended App Academy's 16 week hybrid bootcamp option (now available in-person rather than online). Overall enjoyed the program and feel as though it prepared me well. The curriculum does facilitate your learning and help you pick up more skills on your own after your studies are done. Pros: - Really good instructors (at least for my cohort - Darren/Spencer/Diego were amazing teachers) - Short timeframe to gain the necessary skills/experience - Good project experience to fill out resume and give real world examples of programming - Got a lot of pair programming experience - Good partnership opportunities with certain companies (including some FAANG level opportunities) - Strong sense of community with your cohort Cons: - Some of the curriculum is a little outdated (specifically the React portion could be better). You should 100% learn React hooks after the cohort ends to be ready for frontend interviews (or even before if you feel ambitious). - Homework/instructional videos start out quite good and get to be lower quality towards the end of the course - Advanced data structures and algorithms are mostly just touched upon briefly and not covered in depth, so you'll need to learn them on your own - JavaScript is the language you'll feel strongest in by the end of the program, and it's not ideal to interview in. Ruby is also taught but you won't be using it too actively post week 8 aside from the full stack project, but a lot of companies do not interview in Ruby - After the instruction ends, there are a lot of boilerplate meetings you'll need to go to for the career quest which will slow down your study of data structures and algorithms. If you want to be strong at this, you'll need to really study hard and not take it easy despite graduation While I did list several cons, all of these can be nullified by having a strong work ethic and learning on your own. If you're motivated to do well and want to take a career change seriously, App Academy provides a really good foundation and I would recommend it a lot.

Pros - Good career services with not just counselors but a community that pushes you to learn and grow as a software developer. If you're willing to put in the work to not only produce the projects but also understand the concepts and speak intelligently about approaches to software development, you will get a great job. The classes, with 16 weeks to learn a lot, could sometimes feel a bit dense, but with the amount you're expected to learn in that time period the instructors do a great job of it not seeming too overwhelming or putting too much pressure on the students to learn at a pace they would struggle with Also a huge plus, with the ever-growing industry, people seek out boot camp grads more, and App Academy partnerships are a pre-vetted opportunity to get some great experience under your belt with a good wage. Cons - Very steep learning curve at first - about 65% of our cohort made it to the end. Whether this was a failing on their part to properly understand the material or instructors' inability to pick up on people struggling, this was sad and the process of deferring was handled in a rather macabre way that was needlessly dramatic.

The App Academy 16 week software engineering boot camp was one of the most challenging but rewarding experiences of my life. Comparing my programming knowledge and skill now to when the bootcamp started is truly night and day. You not only learn new programming languages and skills, but you also learn how to time manage and how to handle your stress.

Over 16 weeks at A/A, I went from knowing hardly any code to being able to develop a full stack web app. The instructional team is great, and I feel the teacher-to-student ratio was appropriate. There was always time to go over any questions I had. I enjoyed being able to work with other students and improve my soft skills. Once the curriculum winds down, there are many resources provided to students to assist with job placements.
